Heat a small pot over medium. Add pork belly and cook, stirring often, until some fat has cooked out into the pan and meat is cooked through but not browned, about 3 minutes. Pour off all but 1 Tbsp. fat (if needed). Add onion and cook, stirring often, until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add kimchi and juices and cook, stirring occasionally, until liquid evaporates and kimchi is softened, about 5 minutes.Step 2Add gochugaru, gochujang, and 2 cups water and bring to a simmer over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium and cook, stirring occasionally, until kimchi is very tender and flavors in stew come together, 20–30 minutes.Step 3Add tofu to stew and cook until heated through, about 3 minutes. Divide stew among bowls and top with scallions. Serve with rice alongside.Step 4Do Ahead: Stew can be made 4 days ahead. Let cool; cover and chill.How would you rate Kimchi Jjigae?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (9)Back to TopTriangleThis version is a tad more benign than the version in Chefs Sohui Kim’s cookbook Korean Home Cooking but for an introduction it’s still tasty and comforting. Now that I've seen the comments I might try it the traditional way too.AnonymousVancouver, Canada1/14/2021Now that I see the comments will definitely try the more traditional versions.brushjlsolon, oh12/17/2020Agree with the comment below - this recipe lacks umami/seasoningAnonymousVancouver5/1/2020I love you Bon Appetit, but I’m sorry this recipe is seriously lacking. I would recommend following a more traditional approach with the broth base by adding kelp, anchovies, daikon, and green onions to help create the umami that’s missing.SylveeuhLA9/23/2019OMG, this recipe was spot on for me! Thank you, thank you, thank you Sohui Kim and Bon Appetit!!! The kimchi I used was store bought (eek!!) so the spices were already there, but this was a definitely bowl of comfort just as Sohui Kim said!!!AnonymousAcworth, GA4/26/2019So where is a recipe for the Kimchi???AnonymousTX3/10/2019Thanks for the tips. I used spicy kimchi and didn’t worry about the paste as the previous commenter recommended. A little salt was perfect. Thanks for the tip!AnonymousChicago 3/9/2019I’m not trying to be pedantic here, but traditionally, kimchi jjigae would not have any gochujang in it. Some people add dwenjang (korean miso paste?) depending on the flavor of the kimchi, but we usually don’t add gochujang. We normally use salt for seasoning. Anyways, I’m really happy to see more Korean recipes on here! I’ve always loved Bon Appetit, but I think I love it even more now.
